newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish steel sector profit's plunges in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Polish steel sector profit's plunges in 1996.

text.p: The Polish steel sector's net profit plunged to 21.5 million zlotys last year from 339.9 million zlotys in 1995, according to a report of the Polish Steel Trade Chamber published on Friday.

The report, in Nowa Europa economic daily, said the industry's gross profit fell to 35.6 million zlotys last year from 740.7 million zlotys in 1995, while sales slightly increased to 12.83 billion zlotys from 12.77 billion zlotys.
The Rzeczpospolita business daily also reported that out of Poland's 20 steel mills, seven suffered net and gross losses last year.
Rzeczpospolita quoted the chamber's president Tadeusz Torz as saying the plunge resulted from smaller demand for steel products last year.
The government has said that Polish steel mills, which have invested about $1 billion in modernisation over the last several years, still need some $2.5 billion over the next three years.

The investment is needed to prepare the industry for foreign competition after Poland lifts barriers protecting the sector around 2000. Analysts say the money can come only from foreign strategic investors.
Last year, the then deputy Treasury Minister Wieslaw Kaczmarek said talks were under way with foreign investors on selling Poland's two largest steel mills -- Huta Katowice SA and Huta Sedzimira SA.
